intro: Borreria patula, commonly known as the Mexican mallow, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges. It produces small, pink or white flowers that bloom in clusters, often in the summer months. Borreria patula is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
